stories.text:
I just happened to be consulting the website for APOPO, www.apopo.org "global leader in scent detection animals" (founded by Bart Weetjens in 1995), entity which trains rats to detect landmines by smelling TNT - «The rats can smell TNT in low concentrations and even when it's buried under the ground (up to 15-20 cm)... from a distance of about 1 meter».

As I read that «APOPO’s HeroRATs take around nine months to fully train», the preliminary thought struck, about whether cybernetic deminers, for which training is an "upload", can be worth considering. Maybe the time to build a robot and its costs are competitive. It seems that the more complex part could really be the motility - the landmine sensor may not be something you train, if the revealing substance remains TNT, or the problem seems to remain deterministic, if achieving a database of all the diverse threats is a goal. On the other hand, other techniques that involve e.g. visual clues and other open factors for decision may enhance the results, and call again for dynamic "training".

Also note that the inspiring entity seems to use automation already in their processes: rats can use automated training rooms (they are rewarded for TNT detection).

I find the matter interesting and "important" as an understatement, and maybe some good result could come from opening the topic.
